Location.Explanation: Event 1: isalnum() is invoked here with an argument of signed type char, but only has defined behavior for int arguments that are either representable as unsigned char or equal to the value of macro EOF(-1). * Casting the argument to unsigned char will avoid the undefined behavior. In a number of libc implementations, isalnum() is implemented using lookup tables (arrays): passing in a negative value can result in a read underrun.

Location.Explanation: Event 1: Taking false branch. cp evaluates to false.
Event 2: getenv() returns the address of a new object.

Event 3: Inside getenv(), the length of the string pointed to by getenv("PATH") is set to a potentially dangerous value [potentially dangerous: the value cannot be determined and may come from program input]. * This determines the capacity of the buffer that will be overrun later.
Event 4: Considering the case where the length of the string pointed to by getenv("PATH") is at least 0.
Event 5: Considering the case where the length of the string pointed to by getenv("PATH") is no more than 1073741823.
Event 6: pathlist is set to getenv("PATH"). [event 2]
Event 7: Skipping "if". pathlist == 0 evaluates to false.
Event 8: pathlist, which evaluates to getenv("PATH") [event 2, lemon.c:3290], is passed to strlen(). [event 6]
Event 9: strlen() returns the length of the string pointed to by pathlist, which evaluates to the length of the string pointed to by getenv("PATH") [event 2, lemon.c:3290]. [event 3] [event 8]
Event 10: (int)strlen(pathlist) + 1, which evaluates to the length of the string pointed to by getenv("PATH") [event 2, lemon.c:3290], plus 1, is passed to malloc(). [event 9]
Event 11: malloc() returns the address of a new object. * This points to the buffer that will be overrun later.
Event 12: Inside malloc(), the capacity of the buffer pointed to by malloc(...) is set to the length of the string pointed to by getenv("PATH") [event 2, lemon.c:3290], plus 1. [event 10]
Event 13: pathbuf is set to malloc(...). [event 11]
Event 14: Taking true branch. * pathbuf != 0 evaluates to true. * path != 0 evaluates to true.
Event 15: Entering loop body. *pathbuf evaluates to true.
Event 16: pathbuf, which evaluates to malloc(...) [event 11, lemon.c:3292], is passed to strchr() as the first argument. [event 13]
Event 17: strchr() returns malloc(...) [event 11, lemon.c:3292]. [event 16]
Event 18: cp is set to strchr(pathbuf, 58), which evaluates to malloc(...) [event 11, lemon.c:3292]. [event 17]
Event 19: Skipping "if". cp == 0 evaluates to false.
Event 20: Taking false branch. c == 0 evaluates to false.
Event 21: pathbuf is set to cp + 1, which evaluates to malloc(...) + 1 [event 11, lemon.c:3292]. [event 18]
Event 22: Skipping "if". access(path, modemask) == 0 evaluates to false.

Event 23: This code could read past the end of the buffer pointed to by pathbuf. * pathbuf evaluates to malloc(...) + 1 [event 11, lemon.c:3292]. * The code reads 1 byte starting at offset 1 from the beginning of the buffer pointed to by pathbuf. * The number of bytes read could exceed the number of allocated bytes beyond that offset. * The capacity of the buffer pointed to by pathbuf, in bytes, is the length of the string pointed to by getenv("PATH") [event 2, lemon.c:3290], plus 1, which is bounded above by 1073741824 and below by 1. [event 12] [event 21] * If the length of the string pointed to by getenv("PATH") [event 2, lemon.c:3290], plus 1 is 2 or lower, an overrun will occur. The analysis cannot rule out this possibility, so has issued this warning. * The overrun occurs in heap memory. The issue can occur if the highlighted code executes. [event 4] [event 5] [event 12] [event 21]
